elements.content: Metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) can possess various crystal structures due to the combination of metal ions and organic bridging ligands, resulting in versatile electronic and optical characteristics. The architecture of nanometer-sized MOFs is one of the prime areas of study in producing novel nanomaterials. However, the methodology is still in progress, as relevant research reports remain scarce. In this Article, we report the synthesis of cyano bridged MOFs comprising iron and lanthanide ions (Fe−CN−Ln, Ln = La, Ce, Pr, Nd, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, Lu), generally formulated as Ln[Fe(CN)6] in a water/alcohol dilute solution system containing acetic acid as an additive. Specific morphologies of Fe−CN−Ln such as hexagons, asterisks, and rods with a size of approximately 200−600 nm were observed depending on the particular Ln ions introduced. Specifically, the formation mechanism of nanoasterisks of Fe−CN−Sm was precisely investigated by high-resolution transmission microscopy (HRTEM), which revealed that the nanoasterisks were composed of tiny assembled Fe−CN−Sm nanocrystals of approximately 10−20 nm in diameter. This unique assembled structure of Fe−CN−Sm was constructed with high selectivity only when the additive of acetic acid was incorporated in the synthetic mixture. Thermal transmission electron microscopy (TEM) observation was carried out to clarify the in situ decomposition dynamics. The nanoasterisk of Fe−CN−Sm was observed to convert into an amorphous hollow nanostructure while maintaining the starting asterisk morphology up to 550 °C, with a dramatic increase of the Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) surface area from 6.5 to 175 m2/g. Further heating to 750 °C induced a transition from the amorphous phase to the crystalline phase of SmFeO3, the shape of which could be recognized as the starting asterisk. Upon further heating to 950 °C, the arm-like network of SmFeO3 was predominant, which can be explained by the linkage of the adjacent SmFeO3 asterisk arms. We deduced that the morphology of the final nanomaterials after the thermal conversion reaction was strongly influenced by the morphology of the starting MOF. The present study affords a technological direction toward sophisticated nanomaterial architecture using a bottom-up approach.
elements.clean_text: Metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) can possess various crystal structures due to the combination of metal ions and organic bridging ligands, resulting in versatile electronic and optical characteristics. The architecture of nanometer-sized MOFs is one of the prime areas of study in producing novel nanomaterials. However, the methodology is still in progress, as relevant research reports remain scarce. In this Article, we report the synthesis of cyano bridged MOFs comprising iron and lanthanide ions (Fe−CN−Ln, Ln = La, Ce, Pr, Nd, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, Lu), generally formulated as Ln[Fe(CN)6] in a water/alcohol dilute solution system containing acetic acid as an additive. Specific morphologies of Fe−CN−Ln such as hexagons, asterisks, and rods with a size of approximately 200−600 nm were observed depending on the particular Ln ions introduced. Specifically, the formation mechanism of nanoasterisks of Fe−CN−Sm was precisely investigated by high-resolution transmission microscopy (HRTEM), which revealed that the nanoasterisks were composed of tiny assembled Fe−CN−Sm nanocrystals of approximately 10−20 nm in diameter. This unique assembled structure of Fe−CN−Sm was constructed with high selectivity only when the additive of acetic acid was incorporated in the synthetic mixture. Thermal transmission electron microscopy (TEM) observation was carried out to clarify the in situ decomposition dynamics. The nanoasterisk of Fe−CN−Sm was observed to convert into an amorphous hollow nanostructure while maintaining the starting asterisk morphology up to 550 °C, with a dramatic increase of the Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) surface area from 6.5 to 175 m2/g. Further heating to 750 °C induced a transition from the amorphous phase to the crystalline phase of SmFeO3, the shape of which could be recognized as the starting asterisk. Upon further heating to 950 °C, the arm-like network of SmFeO3 was predominant, which can be explained by the linkage of the adjacent SmFeO3 asterisk arms. We deduced that the morphology of the final nanomaterials after the thermal conversion reaction was strongly influenced by the morphology of the starting MOF. The present study affords a technological direction toward sophisticated nanomaterial architecture using a bottom-up approach.

elements.content: Research into inorganic nanoparticles (NPs) has attracted a great deal of attention because NPs have certain properties, optical, catalytic, and magnetic, that are dramatically different from those of bulk materials. The difference is due to the quantum size effect and the large surface-to-volume ratio of NPs. A wide range of inorganic substances have been prepared as NPs, ranging from metals (Au, Pt, Fe, Si, AuAg, PtFe, NiAl, etc.) to metal oxides (TiO2, Fe2O3, CoFe2O4, etc.). In contrast, relatively few reports about 3D metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) on the nanometer scale are available to date. MOF NPs may potentially find a broad application due to their bulk properties, such as magnetism, electrochromism, fluorescence, gas adsorption, and metal/metal oxide precursers. Desirable characteristics can be systematically designed by the appropriate selection of metal ions and organic bridging ligands. Regarding the challenge of constructing nanometric MOFs, Vaucher et al. first reported that the downsizing of MOFs (Prussian blue analogues) was possible by crystallizing them in a nanometer-sized water droplet of a reverse micelle solution. Since then, several approaches have appeared over the past several years, for example, the use of reverse micelles, inorganic templates, and crystallization from a dilute solution. The stable isolation of MOF NPs in air as a powdery form is also possible by surface protection, which would enable further facile processing to use them as a nanodevice on a substrate. Subsequently, it is of interest that the morphology of MOF NPs can be controlled via a synthetic procedure because the morphology of nanocrystals is an important determinant of their properties. Up to now, several shapes (e.g., spheres, cubes, ribbons, rings, and rods) have been reported for MOF NPs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
Research into inorganic nanoparticles (NPs) has attracted a great deal of attention because NPs have certain properties, optical, catalytic, and magnetic, that are dramatically different from those of bulk materials. The difference is due to the quantum size effect and the large surface-to-volume ratio of NPs. A wide range of inorganic substances have been prepared as NPs, ranging from metals (Au, Pt, Fe, Si, AuAg, PtFe, NiAl, etc.) to metal oxides (TiO2, Fe2O3, CoFe2O4, etc.). In contrast, relatively few reports about 3D metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) on the nanometer scale are available to date. MOF NPs may potentially find a broad application due to their bulk properties, such as magnetism, electrochromism, fluorescence, gas adsorption, and metal/metal oxide precursers. Desirable characteristics can be systematically designed by the appropriate selection of metal ions and organic bridging ligands. Regarding the challenge of constructing nanometric MOFs, Vaucher et al. first reported that the downsizing of MOFs (Prussian blue analogues) was possible by crystallizing them in a nanometer-sized water droplet of a reverse micelle solution. Since then, several approaches have appeared over the past several years, for example, the use of reverse micelles, inorganic templates, and crystallization from a dilute solution. The stable isolation of MOF NPs in air as a powdery form is also possible by surface protection, which would enable further facile processing to use them as a nanodevice on a substrate. Subsequently, it is of interest that the morphology of MOF NPs can be controlled via a synthetic procedure because the morphology of nanocrystals is an important determinant of their properties. Up to now, several shapes (e.g., spheres, cubes, ribbons, rings, and rods) have been reported for MOF NPs.

elements.content: In the present study, we selected a cyano bridged MOF comprising iron and lanthanide ions (Fe−CN−Ln; Ln = La, Ce, Pr, Nd, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, Lu), generally formulated as Ln[Fe(CN)6]. Fe−CN−Ln is one of the widely known MOFs and can be synthesized simply by mixing the starting materials, Fe(CN)3− and Ln3+, in solution. As the resulting Fe−CN−Ln is stable in air, Fe−CN−Ln can become a typical model case to investigate the methodology of fabricating nanometric MOFs. The synthesis of Fe−CN−Gd NPs and Fe−CN−Sm NPs was reported in previous studies. However, this is the first report to investigate the synthesis and the morphology of Fe−CN−Ln NPs that cover all 4f Ln ions. It should also be mentioned that Fe−CN−Ln is usually synthesized in an “aqueous” solution. The synthetic variation can be expanded when Fe−CN−Ln are crystallized in a solvent other than water. Therefore, we introduced a rather hydrophobic anion of Et4N+ as a counterion of Fe(CN)3− and investigated the novel synthesis of Fe−CN−Ln NPs in a dilute water/alcohol solution. We noticed that in some cases the crystal morphology of inorganic crystals is highly influenced by an additive. Here, acetic acid (CH3COOH) was incorporated into the synthetic solution of Fe−CN−Ln NPs, as the carboxylic group of acetic acid was expected to interact with Ln3+ cations and afford some effect on the morphology of Fe−CN−Ln NPs. We demonstrated that in our synthetic system, the morphology of Fe−CN−Ln NPs was significantly influenced by the type of Ln introduced. The most interesting morphology was the “asterisk”, the shape selectivity for which was relatively high for Fe−CN−Sm NPs. The formation mechanism of nanoasterisks of Fe−CN−Sm was elucidated in detail using transmission microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution transmission microscopy (HRTEM), suggesting that this nanoasterisk is a rare example of the specific assembled structure comprising tiny nanocrystals of MOFs. In the second stage, we targeted the question of how such a unique morphology of MOFs works as a precursor for inorganic nanomaterials. The thermal conversion reaction of the “isolated” nanoasterisk of Fe−CN−Sm was successfully observed by in situ direct thermal TEM. The results revealed that the nanoasterisk was gradually converted to a porous hollow substance while retaining the starting asterisk morphology. The hollow porous material was finally converted to SmFeO3 nanocrystals with quasi-asterisk or arm-like networks throughout the continuous calcination process. Consequently, we demonstrated that the shape of the starting MOF NPs was very influential for the morphological manipulation of the mixed-metal−oxide NPs.
elements.clean_text: In the present study, we selected a cyano bridged MOF comprising iron and lanthanide ions (Fe−CN−Ln; Ln = La, Ce, Pr, Nd, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, Lu), generally formulated as Ln[Fe(CN)6]. Fe−CN−Ln is one of the widely known MOFs and can be synthesized simply by mixing the starting materials, Fe(CN)3− and Ln3+, in solution. As the resulting Fe−CN−Ln is stable in air, Fe−CN−Ln can become a typical model case to investigate the methodology of fabricating nanometric MOFs. The synthesis of Fe−CN−Gd NPs and Fe−CN−Sm NPs was reported in previous studies. However, this is the first report to investigate the synthesis and the morphology of Fe−CN−Ln NPs that cover all 4f Ln ions. It should also be mentioned that Fe−CN−Ln is usually synthesized in an “aqueous” solution. The synthetic variation can be expanded when Fe−CN−Ln are crystallized in a solvent other than water. Therefore, we introduced a rather hydrophobic anion of Et4N+ as a counterion of Fe(CN)3− and investigated the novel synthesis of Fe−CN−Ln NPs in a dilute water/alcohol solution. We noticed that in some cases the crystal morphology of inorganic crystals is highly influenced by an additive. Here, acetic acid (CH3COOH) was incorporated into the synthetic solution of Fe−CN−Ln NPs, as the carboxylic group of acetic acid was expected to interact with Ln3+ cations and afford some effect on the morphology of Fe−CN−Ln NPs. We demonstrated that in our synthetic system, the morphology of Fe−CN−Ln NPs was significantly influenced by the type of Ln introduced. The most interesting morphology was the “asterisk”, the shape selectivity for which was relatively high for Fe−CN−Sm NPs. The formation mechanism of nanoasterisks of Fe−CN−Sm was elucidated in detail using transmission microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution transmission microscopy (HRTEM), suggesting that this nanoasterisk is a rare example of the specific assembled structure comprising tiny nanocrystals of MOFs. In the second stage, we targeted the question of how such a unique morphology of MOFs works as a precursor for inorganic nanomaterials. The thermal conversion reaction of the “isolated” nanoasterisk of Fe−CN−Sm was successfully observed by in situ direct thermal TEM. The results revealed that the nanoasterisk was gradually converted to a porous hollow substance while retaining the starting asterisk morphology. The hollow porous material was finally converted to SmFeO3 nanocrystals with quasi-asterisk or arm-like networks throughout the continuous calcination process. Consequently, we demonstrated that the shape of the starting MOF NPs was very influential for the morphological manipulation of the mixed-metal−oxide NPs.

elements.content: All starting chemicals were of the purest commercially available grade. K3[Fe(CN)6], Et4NBr, CH3(CH2)10COOH, CH3(CH2)11SH, CH3(CH2)11OH, CH3(CH2)11NH2, CH3COOH, methanol, diethyl ether, ethanol, acetonitrile, hexane, and KBr for FT-IR were purchased from Wako Chemicals. Ln(NO3)3·6H2O (Ln = La, Ce, Pr, Nd, Sm, Gd, Tb), Ln(NO3)3·5H2O (Ln = Eu, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb), and Lu(NO3)3·H2O were purchased from Aldrich. Deionized water was used for all syntheses and was obtained from a Millipore Milli-Q SP. The resistivity of the water was confirmed to be over 18.3 MΩ cm.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Methods
Chemicals
All starting chemicals were of the purest commercially available grade. K3[Fe(CN)6], Et4NBr, CH3(CH2)10COOH, CH3(CH2)11SH, CH3(CH2)11OH, CH3(CH2)11NH2, CH3COOH, methanol, diethyl ether, ethanol, acetonitrile, hexane, and KBr for FT-IR were purchased from Wako Chemicals. Ln(NO3)3·6H2O (Ln = La, Ce, Pr, Nd, Sm, Gd, Tb), Ln(NO3)3·5H2O (Ln = Eu, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb), and Lu(NO3)3·H2O were purchased from Aldrich. Deionized water was used for all syntheses and was obtained from a Millipore Milli-Q SP. The resistivity of the water was confirmed to be over 18.3 MΩ cm.

elements.content: The starting cyano complex of (Et4N)3[Fe(CN)6] was synthesized according to the previous literature. Briefly, K3[Fe(CN)6] (3.3 g, 10 mmol) and Et4NBr (6.3 g, 30 mmol) were dissolved in methanol and stirred at 30 °C for 3 days under a N2 atmosphere. The mixture was filtered by Celite, and the filtrate was concentrated to ∼10 mL by a rotary evaporator. The resulting solution was added to 50 mL of diethyl ether, and the precipitate was collected by a membrane filter. The crude product was dissolved in 100 mL of acetonitrile with reflux, and the solution was cooled naturally to crystallize the purified (Et4N)3[Fe(CN)6] powder, which exhibited a pale yellow color.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of (Et4N)3[Fe(CN)6]
The starting cyano complex of (Et4N)3[Fe(CN)6] was synthesized according to the previous literature. Briefly, K3[Fe(CN)6] (3.3 g, 10 mmol) and Et4NBr (6.3 g, 30 mmol) were dissolved in methanol and stirred at 30 °C for 3 days under a N2 atmosphere. The mixture was filtered by Celite, and the filtrate was concentrated to ∼10 mL by a rotary evaporator. The resulting solution was added to 50 mL of diethyl ether, and the precipitate was collected by a membrane filter. The crude product was dissolved in 100 mL of acetonitrile with reflux, and the solution was cooled naturally to crystallize the purified (Et4N)3[Fe(CN)6] powder, which exhibited a pale yellow color.

elements.content: CH3COOH (0.94 g, 18 mmol) and Ln(NO)3·xH2O (0.20 mmol) were dissolved in 35 mL of H2O/ethanol (2: 5 v/v). The solution was added to 2 mL of methanol, dissolving (Et4N)3[Fe(CN)6] (0.12 g, 0.20 mmol) at the same time, and the mixture was kept at 25 °C for 2.5 h without stirring. The precipitate was filtered twice with sufficient ethanol wash and dried in vacuo to obtain powdery Fe−CN−M NPs. As for Fe−CN−Sm NPs, CH3(CH2)10COOH, CH3(CH2)11SH, CH3(CH2)11OH, and CH3(CH2)11NH2 were also used in place of CH3COOH to investigate the additive effect on the morphology of Fe−CN−Sm NPs.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Fe−CN−Ln NPs (Ln = La, Ce, Pr, Nd, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, Lu)
CH3COOH (0.94 g, 18 mmol) and Ln(NO)3·xH2O (0.20 mmol) were dissolved in 35 mL of H2O/ethanol (2: 5 v/v). The solution was added to 2 mL of methanol, dissolving (Et4N)3[Fe(CN)6] (0.12 g, 0.20 mmol) at the same time, and the mixture was kept at 25 °C for 2.5 h without stirring. The precipitate was filtered twice with sufficient ethanol wash and dried in vacuo to obtain powdery Fe−CN−M NPs. As for Fe−CN−Sm NPs, CH3(CH2)10COOH, CH3(CH2)11SH, CH3(CH2)11OH, and CH3(CH2)11NH2 were also used in place of CH3COOH to investigate the additive effect on the morphology of Fe−CN−Sm NPs.

data.symbol: Ln = La, Ce, Pr, Nd, Sm, Eu, Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, Lu

elements.content: Transmission microscopy (TEM) of the samples was performed with a Hitachi H-700 at an accelerating voltage of 100 kV. All of the samples for TEM were prepared by casting the methanol dispersion of the compounds over standard carbon-coated copper grids (Okenshoji, 200 mesh). High-resolution transmission microscopy (HRTEM) was performed with a JEOL JEM-2100 at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The thermal decomposition dynamics of Fe−CN−Sm NPs prepared with CH3COOH were observed using a JEOL JEM-3000F with an operating voltage of 100 kV and heating of the TEM grid stage from rt to 550 °C. The metal elemental composition of the samples was determined using an energy-dispersive fluorescent X-ray analysis (EDX) with a Horiba E-MAX-7000. BET surface area was determined by the Kr adsorption isotherm at rt using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples mounted on an amorphous silicon plate were measured with a Rigaku RINT 2000 diffractometer with Cu Kα (50 mV, 50 mA) radiation from 10° to 90° (2θ value) at a scan rate of 5.000° min−1. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of samples dispersed in KBr disks were recorded on a JASCO FT/IR-4200 spectrophotometer at 4000−500 cm−1. Thermogravimetric thermal analysis (TGA) curves were obtained using a Shimadzu TGA-50 with an increasing rate of 2 °C min−1.
elements.clean_text:
Measurement
Transmission microscopy (TEM) of the samples was performed with a Hitachi H-700 at an accelerating voltage of 100 kV. All of the samples for TEM were prepared by casting the methanol dispersion of the compounds over standard carbon-coated copper grids (Okenshoji, 200 mesh). High-resolution transmission microscopy (HRTEM) was performed with a JEOL JEM-2100 at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The thermal decomposition dynamics of Fe−CN−Sm NPs prepared with CH3COOH were observed using a JEOL JEM-3000F with an operating voltage of 100 kV and heating of the TEM grid stage from rt to 550 °C. The metal elemental composition of the samples was determined using an energy-dispersive fluorescent X-ray analysis (EDX) with a Horiba E-MAX-7000. BET surface area was determined by the Kr adsorption isotherm at rt using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples mounted on an amorphous silicon plate were measured with a Rigaku RINT 2000 diffractometer with Cu Kα (50 mV, 50 mA) radiation from 10° to 90° (2θ value) at a scan rate of 5.000° min−1. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of samples dispersed in KBr disks were recorded on a JASCO FT/IR-4200 spectrophotometer at 4000−500 cm−1. Thermogravimetric thermal analysis (TGA) curves were obtained using a Shimadzu TGA-50 with an increasing rate of 2 °C min−1.

elements.content: Figure shows the TEM images of the Fe−CN−Ln NPs prepared with CH3COOH. The morphology of Fe−CN−Ln is strongly dependent on the type of Ln introduced. When a lower-atomic-number Ln is introduced (Ln = La, Ce, Pr, Nd), mainly hexagon crystals are observed. The hexagon sides are approximately 600 nm (La) or 200−300 nm (Ce, Pr, Nd). On the other hand, higher atomic numbers produce a rod shape (Ln = Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, Lu). The length along the long axis is approximately 200−400, and the width is approximately 50−100 nm. It is noteworthy that the middle atomic number induces the specific morphology of an asterisk (Ln = Sm, Eu). The length of one arm is approximately 400 nm (Ln = Sm) or approximately 500 nm (Ln = Eu). Specifically, the shape selectivity of the so-called “nano-asterisk” was found to be very high for Fe−CN−Sm NPs (see below). Overall, the crystal size of Fe−CN−Ln tends to decrease with a decreasing atomic number of Ln. It is reasonable that the ionic radius of Ln3+ shrinks almost proportionally from 1.03 Å (Ln = La) to 0.86 Å (Ln = Lu) (coordination number: 6) with a decreasing atomic number due to lanthanide contraction.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion
Characterization of Fe−CN−Ln NPs
Figure  shows the TEM images of the Fe−CN−Ln NPs prepared with CH3COOH. The morphology of Fe−CN−Ln is strongly dependent on the type of Ln introduced. When a lower-atomic-number Ln is introduced (Ln = La, Ce, Pr, Nd), mainly hexagon crystals are observed. The hexagon sides are approximately 600 nm (La) or 200−300 nm (Ce, Pr, Nd). On the other hand, higher atomic numbers produce a rod shape (Ln = Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, Lu). The length along the long axis is approximately 200−400, and the width is approximately 50−100 nm. It is noteworthy that the middle atomic number induces the specific morphology of an asterisk (Ln = Sm, Eu). The length of one arm is approximately 400 nm (Ln = Sm) or approximately 500 nm (Ln = Eu). Specifically, the shape selectivity of the so-called “nano-asterisk” was found to be very high for Fe−CN−Sm NPs (see below). Overall, the crystal size of Fe−CN−Ln tends to decrease with a decreasing atomic number of Ln. It is reasonable that the ionic radius of Ln3+ shrinks almost proportionally from 1.03 Å (Ln = La) to 0.86 Å (Ln = Lu) (coordination number: 6) with a decreasing atomic number due to lanthanide contraction.

crystal_size.material: Fe−CN−Ln (Ln = Gd, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, Lu)

elements.content: TEM images of Fe−CN−Ln NPs. The type of Ln is noted in each figure.
elements.clean_text:
1

TEM images of Fe−CN−Ln NPs. The type of Ln is noted in each figure.

elements.content: Some samples of Fe−CN−Ln were selected from three morphology types, hexagon (Ln = La, Nd), asterisk (Ln = Sm, Eu), and rod (Ln Dy, Er, Lu), and their crystal structures were further investigated by XRD (Figure ). All of the XRD patterns exhibit the orthorhombic crystal structure representing SmFe(CN)6·4H2O (JCPDS no. 84-1954). The ratio of Ln to Fe in the compound was confirmed to be approximately 1 for all compounds, as determined by EDX (). Table summarizes the lattice constants a, b, c and the average crystal size d av calculated from the average peak half-width of the XRD patterns using Scherrer’s equation. For example, the crystal constant of Fe−CN−Sm NPs was calculated as a = 0.7458 nm, b = 1.290 nm, and c = 1.376 nm; these values are consistent with those of the bulk crystal. Table clearly demonstrates that the values of a, b, c, and d av become smaller from La to Lu, which agrees with the trend observed by TEM (see above).
elements.clean_text:
Some samples of Fe−CN−Ln were selected from three morphology types, hexagon (Ln = La, Nd), asterisk (Ln = Sm, Eu), and rod (Ln Dy, Er, Lu), and their crystal structures were further investigated by XRD (Figure ). All of the XRD patterns exhibit the orthorhombic crystal structure representing SmFe(CN)6·4H2O (JCPDS no. 84-1954). The ratio of Ln to Fe in the compound was confirmed to be approximately 1 for all compounds, as determined by EDX (). Table  summarizes the lattice constants a, b, c and the average crystal size d
av calculated from the average peak half-width of the XRD patterns using Scherrer’s equation. For example, the crystal constant of Fe−CN−Sm NPs was calculated as a = 0.7458 nm, b = 1.290 nm, and c = 1.376 nm; these values are consistent with those of the bulk crystal. Table  clearly demonstrates that the values of a, b, c, and d
av become smaller from La to Lu, which agrees with the trend observed by TEM (see above).

elements.content: The FT-IR spectra of Fe−CN−Ln NPs displayed two distinct peaks due to a stretching at approximately 2050 and approximately 2130 cm−1, the value of which was shifted from that of the starting (Et4N)3[Fe(CN)6], with a single peak at 2115 cm−1 (Figure ). These results suggest that two different stretching modes of CN are generated after the complexation between Fe(CN)6 3− and Ln3+. Considering that the general bulk crystal of FeCN−Ln prepared in water shows the single CN stretching peak at 2140 cm−1, the low energy peak at 2050 cm−1 of Fe−CN−Ln NPs is originated from ferrocyanide [FeII(CN)6 4−], which is produced by the reduction of FeIII(CN)6 3− by alcohol in this synthetic method. The broad peak at approximately 1600 cm−1 was assigned to a CO stretching band, suggesting that acetic acid molecules were attached to the crystal surface of Fe−CN−Ln NPs through the interaction between the carboxylic group of CH3COO− and Ln3+. One plausible interpretation for this observation is that the morphological dependence on the type of Ln (hexagon, asterisk, and rod) might originate from differences in the interactions between CH3COO− and Ln3+. Simultaneously, it should be noted that a broad vibrating peak around 1450 cm−1 was identified, which is attributed to the C−N stretching mode of Et4N+ comprising the starting (Et4N)3[Fe(CN)6]. In contrast with CH3COO−, Et4N+ might interact with [Fe(CN)6]3− and might affect the crystal growth of Fe−CN−Ln NPs. A previous paper reported that nanorods or nanobelts of Fe−CN−Sm can be obtained from a solution containing cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB). In that paper, the authors speculated that the cetyltrimethylammonium cations (CTA+) could specifically interact with the {001} faces of Fe−CN−Sm crystals, leading to preferred crystal growth in the [001] direction, resulting in a rod or a belt shape. This explanation could also apply to our system, such that Et4N+ functions in the same way as CTA+. However, in our synthesis method, a new mechanism is proposed in which the role of alkylammonium cations (here Et4N+) is mainly as a surface-active agent to provide some soft nanotemplates in solution, rather than a surface adsorptive ion that induces crystal growth of a specific facet (see below).
elements.clean_text:
The FT-IR spectra of Fe−CN−Ln NPs displayed two distinct peaks due to a stretching at approximately 2050 and approximately 2130 cm−1, the value of which was shifted from that of the starting (Et4N)3[Fe(CN)6], with a single peak at 2115 cm−1 (Figure ). These results suggest that two different stretching modes of CN are generated after the complexation between Fe(CN)6
3− and Ln3+. Considering that the general bulk crystal of FeCN−Ln prepared in water shows the single CN stretching peak at 2140 cm−1, the low energy peak at 2050 cm−1 of Fe−CN−Ln NPs is originated from ferrocyanide [FeII(CN)6
4−], which is produced by the reduction of FeIII(CN)6
3− by alcohol in this synthetic method. The broad peak at approximately 1600 cm−1 was assigned to a CO stretching band, suggesting that acetic acid molecules were attached to the crystal surface of Fe−CN−Ln NPs through the interaction between the carboxylic group of CH3COO− and Ln3+. One plausible interpretation for this observation is that the morphological dependence on the type of Ln (hexagon, asterisk, and rod) might originate from differences in the interactions between CH3COO− and Ln3+. Simultaneously, it should be noted that a broad vibrating peak around 1450 cm−1 was identified, which is attributed to the C−N stretching mode of Et4N+ comprising the starting (Et4N)3[Fe(CN)6]. In contrast with CH3COO−, Et4N+ might interact with [Fe(CN)6]3− and might affect the crystal growth of Fe−CN−Ln NPs. A previous paper reported that nanorods or nanobelts of Fe−CN−Sm can be obtained from a solution containing cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB). In that paper, the authors speculated that the cetyltrimethylammonium cations (CTA+) could specifically interact with the {001} faces of Fe−CN−Sm crystals, leading to preferred crystal growth in the [001] direction, resulting in a rod or a belt shape. This explanation could also apply to our system, such that Et4N+ functions in the same way as CTA+. However, in our synthesis method, a new mechanism is proposed in which the role of alkylammonium cations (here Et4N+) is mainly as a surface-active agent to provide some soft nanotemplates in solution, rather than a surface adsorptive ion that induces crystal growth of a specific facet (see below).

elements.content: FT-IR spectra of Fe−CN−Ln NPs and (Et4N)3[Fe(CN)6]. The type of Ln is noted for each curve.
elements.clean_text:
3

FT-IR spectra of Fe−CN−Ln NPs and (Et4N)3[Fe(CN)6]. The type of Ln is noted for each curve.

elements.content: We focused on the unique morphology of the asterisk (Ln = Sm) and explored its physical construction in detail using TEM and HRTEM. Figure a shows the wide-range TEM image of Fe−CN−Sm nanoasterisks, which indicates that the shape selectivity for asterisks is very high (more than 80%). Interestingly, its HRTEM image reveals that the nanoasterisk is not a single crystal, but rather a polycrystalline structure comprised of assembled Fe−CN−Sm nanocrystals having a diameter of 10−20 nm (Figure b). We confirmed that the Fe−CN−Sm nanocrystals have lattice spacings of 0.59 and 0.26 nm, attributed to the (111) and (223) planes of Sm[Fe(CN)6], respectively (Figure c). However, the crystal clearly does not grow along one axis only, supporting our proposed hypothesis that the ammonium cation of Et4N+ does not function as a surface-adsorptive agent that accelerates a specific crystal facet to produce the peculiar shape of Fe−CN−Ln (see above).
elements.clean_text:
Formation Analysis of Fe−CN−Sm Nanoasterisks
We focused on the unique morphology of the asterisk (Ln = Sm) and explored its physical construction in detail using TEM and HRTEM. Figure a shows the wide-range TEM image of Fe−CN−Sm nanoasterisks, which indicates that the shape selectivity for asterisks is very high (more than 80%). Interestingly, its HRTEM image reveals that the nanoasterisk is not a single crystal, but rather a polycrystalline structure comprised of assembled Fe−CN−Sm nanocrystals having a diameter of 10−20 nm (Figure b). We confirmed that the Fe−CN−Sm nanocrystals have lattice spacings of 0.59 and 0.26 nm, attributed to the (111) and (223) planes of Sm[Fe(CN)6], respectively (Figure c). However, the crystal clearly does not grow along one axis only, supporting our proposed hypothesis that the ammonium cation of Et4N+ does not function as a surface-adsorptive agent that accelerates a specific crystal facet to produce the peculiar shape of Fe−CN−Ln (see above).

elements.content: (a) TEM and (b,c) HRTEM images of Fe−CN−Sm nanoasterisks.
elements.clean_text:
4

(a) TEM and (b,c) HRTEM images of Fe−CN−Sm nanoasterisks.

elements.content: To more precisely elucidate the formation mechanism in this system, we examined the dependence of morphology on reaction time, as shown in Figure . Within 30 s of the beginning of the reaction, spherical nuclei of Fe−CN−Sm (approximately 20 nm in diameter) were mainly observed (Figure a). At the same time, both a necklace assembled by several nuclei and a rod-shaped structure were identified in certain locations (Figure a, inset, and Figure b). After 3 min, the asterisk morphology began to appear (Figure d), and the arm comprised the assembled rod crystals (Figure c). It should be mentioned that the crystal was not fully packed at this stage, as spaces between the rods were readily observed (Figure d). When the reaction proceeded further, these space defects were finally filled with nanocrystals, resulting in the complete asterisk-formed polycrystalline morphology of Fe−CN−Sm (Figure , Ln = Sm).
elements.clean_text: To more precisely elucidate the formation mechanism in this system, we examined the dependence of morphology on reaction time, as shown in Figure . Within 30 s of the beginning of the reaction, spherical nuclei of Fe−CN−Sm (approximately 20 nm in diameter) were mainly observed (Figure a). At the same time, both a necklace assembled by several nuclei and a rod-shaped structure were identified in certain locations (Figure a, inset, and Figure b). After 3 min, the asterisk morphology began to appear (Figure d), and the arm comprised the assembled rod crystals (Figure c). It should be mentioned that the crystal was not fully packed at this stage, as spaces between the rods were readily observed (Figure d). When the reaction proceeded further, these space defects were finally filled with nanocrystals, resulting in the complete asterisk-formed polycrystalline morphology of Fe−CN−Sm (Figure , Ln = Sm).

elements.content: Formation analysis of Fe−CN−Sm nanoasterisks: TEM and HRTEM images of the compound with a reaction time of (a,b) 30 s and (c,d) 3 min.
elements.clean_text:
5

Formation analysis of Fe−CN−Sm nanoasterisks: TEM and HRTEM images of the compound with a reaction time of (a,b) 30 s and (c,d) 3 min.

elements.content: Note that acetic acid plays a crucial role in the formation of the asterisk morphology, because the rod structure was mostly obtained without acetic acid in the mixture (Figure a). This result indicates that the reaction conditions of this system tend to generate a rod shape of Fe−CN−Ln, as evident in Figure . It is surprising that the prime structure also changed from an asterisk to a rod when the acetic acid was replaced with a hydrophobic ligand of CH3(CH2)10COOH (Figure b). In addition, the substitution of acetic acid with coordinating ligands lacking a carboxylic group (C12H26OH, C12H26NH2, C12H26SH) produced quasi-spherical nanoparticles (Figure c−e). These stronger coordination ligands (NH2, SH, and OH) are likely attached to the surfaces of the Sm sites of the Fe−CN−Sm nanoparticles, in contrast to carboxylic ligands, and govern the morphological control, resulting in spherical particles due to the minimization of their surface energy. Consequently, these series of experiments deduced that the critical factor in constructing the asterisk assembly in this reaction is a “hydrophilic” additive with a “carboxylic” group (i.e., acetic acid). The effect of the ligand on the physical structure of nanoparticles (shape, size, aggregation of the particles) remains a subject of controversy. As for the assembly of the particles, previous papers have reported that inorganic nanoparticles aggregate to form a wire- or a rod-like structure when they were dissolved in a solution containing a surface active agent, such as PEG or C12E4. Considering all of the obtained results, a plausible formation mechanism for Fe−CN−Sm nanoasterisks is that Et4N+ works effectively as a cationic surfactant, cooperating with acetic acid to function as a soft template that forces Fe−CN−Sm nanocrystals to assemble in the asterisk morphology. This phenomenon can be deduced as a unique example of a nanometer-sized MOF structure specifically formed by the assembly of nuclei.
elements.clean_text: Note that acetic acid plays a crucial role in the formation of the asterisk morphology, because the rod structure was mostly obtained without acetic acid in the mixture (Figure a). This result indicates that the reaction conditions of this system tend to generate a rod shape of Fe−CN−Ln, as evident in Figure . It is surprising that the prime structure also changed from an asterisk to a rod when the acetic acid was replaced with a hydrophobic ligand of CH3(CH2)10COOH (Figure b). In addition, the substitution of acetic acid with coordinating ligands lacking a carboxylic group (C12H26OH, C12H26NH2, C12H26SH) produced quasi-spherical nanoparticles (Figure c−e). These stronger coordination ligands (NH2, SH, and OH) are likely attached to the surfaces of the Sm sites of the Fe−CN−Sm nanoparticles, in contrast to carboxylic ligands, and govern the morphological control, resulting in spherical particles due to the minimization of their surface energy. Consequently, these series of experiments deduced that the critical factor in constructing the asterisk assembly in this reaction is a “hydrophilic” additive with a “carboxylic” group (i.e., acetic acid). The effect of the ligand on the physical structure of nanoparticles (shape, size, aggregation of the particles) remains a subject of controversy. As for the assembly of the particles, previous papers have reported that inorganic nanoparticles aggregate to form a wire- or a rod-like structure when they were dissolved in a solution containing a surface active agent, such as PEG or C12E4. Considering all of the obtained results, a plausible formation mechanism for Fe−CN−Sm nanoasterisks is that Et4N+ works effectively as a cationic surfactant, cooperating with acetic acid to function as a soft template that forces Fe−CN−Sm nanocrystals to assemble in the asterisk morphology. This phenomenon can be deduced as a unique example of a nanometer-sized MOF structure specifically formed by the assembly of nuclei.

TEM image of Fe−CN−Sm NPs prepared in the reaction mixture noted in the experimental section of the text (a) without acetic acid and with (b) CH3(CH2)10COOH, (c) CH3(CH2)11OH, (d) CH3(CH2)11NH2, or (e) CH3(CH2)11SH in place of acetic acid.

elements.content: The synthesis of mixed-metal−oxide nanoparticles is attracting a great deal of interest because of their wide range of applications. In particular, bulk-crystal Fe−CN−Ln is known to function as an excellent precursor to a perovskite-type functional oxide of LnFeO3 (e.g., catalysts, gas separators, sensors, etc.) via calcination in air because of the similar structural configuration of atoms between these two structures. In the last section, we turn our attention to the function of the prepared Fe−CN−Sm nanoasterisks as precursors of mixed-metal−oxide nanoparticles. An interesting question for nanomaterial fabrication remains in regards to how Fe−CN−Sm nanoasterisks with a well-defined morphology are dynamically converted to SmFeO3 nanoparticles. We successfully monitored the thermolysis process of the nanoasterisks directly using in situ TEM observations.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Conversion Reaction of the Fe−CN−Sm Nanoasterisk
The synthesis of mixed-metal−oxide nanoparticles is attracting a great deal of interest because of their wide range of applications. In particular, bulk-crystal Fe−CN−Ln is known to function as an excellent precursor to a perovskite-type functional oxide of LnFeO3 (e.g., catalysts, gas separators, sensors, etc.) via calcination in air because of the similar structural configuration of atoms between these two structures. In the last section, we turn our attention to the function of the prepared Fe−CN−Sm nanoasterisks as precursors of mixed-metal−oxide nanoparticles. An interesting question for nanomaterial fabrication remains in regards to how Fe−CN−Sm nanoasterisks with a well-defined morphology are dynamically converted to SmFeO3 nanoparticles. We successfully monitored the thermolysis process of the nanoasterisks directly using in situ TEM observations.

elements.content: We first confirmed that the removal of the bridging ligand CN of the Fe−CN−Sm nanoasterisks occurs in the temperature range from 200 to 300 °C. Subsequently, a single Fe−CN−Sm nanoasterisk on a TEM grid was focused on () and heated from rt to 550 °C during the TEM observation (Figure b−d). As the temperature increased, tiny, darkly contrasted spots appeared at 250 °C (Figure b). Some of the arms began to bend, and the particle uniformly shrank at 350 °C (Figure c). The dark areas are attributed to the development of inorganic aggregated species due to the thermal decomposition of the CN bridging ligand. At 550 °C, the surface porosity and the arm bending were more exaggerated, while the starting asterisk morphology was clearly maintained (Figure d). The HRTEM image of the final sample exhibited a hollow nanostructure comprising almost uniform interconnected domains of approximately 10 nm diameter (Figure a and b). The electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of the selected area displayed no specific signals (Figure c), suggesting that the compound possesses an amorphous structure. The Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) surface area of the compound dramatically increased from 6.5 to 175.2 m2/g before and after the calcinations due to the production of pores (Table ).
elements.clean_text: We first confirmed that the removal of the bridging ligand CN of the Fe−CN−Sm nanoasterisks occurs in the temperature range from 200 to 300 °C. Subsequently, a single Fe−CN−Sm nanoasterisk on a TEM grid was focused on () and heated from rt to 550 °C during the TEM observation (Figure b−d). As the temperature increased, tiny, darkly contrasted spots appeared at 250 °C (Figure b). Some of the arms began to bend, and the particle uniformly shrank at 350 °C (Figure c). The dark areas are attributed to the development of inorganic aggregated species due to the thermal decomposition of the CN bridging ligand. At 550 °C, the surface porosity and the arm bending were more exaggerated, while the starting asterisk morphology was clearly maintained (Figure d). The HRTEM image of the final sample exhibited a hollow nanostructure comprising almost uniform interconnected domains of approximately 10 nm diameter (Figure a and b). The electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of the selected area displayed no specific signals (Figure c), suggesting that the compound possesses an amorphous structure. The Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) surface area of the compound dramatically increased from 6.5 to 175.2 m2/g before and after the calcinations due to the production of pores (Table ).

other properties: surface area increased from 6.5 to 175.2 m2/g

Relationship between the BET Surface Area of the Fe−CN−Sm Nanoasterisks and the Calcination Temperature

| temperature/°C | rt   | 550  | 750 | 950 |

| BET surface area/m^2^/g | 6.5  | 175.2 | 9.7 | 7.5 |

elements.content: Figure shows the XRD patterns of the Fe−CN−Sm nanoasterisks calcined in air at different temperatures as a powdery form. The pattern of the sample heated to below 550 °C did not exhibit distinct diffraction peaks, displaying a broadened peak in the low angle region at approximately 30°. The sample was considered to be an amorphous phase, which agrees well with the in situ thermal TEM observations (see above). The constituents of SmFeO3 (Sm, Fe, and O ions) did not crystallize, even though the bridging CN ligands of the Fe−CN−Sm nanoasterisk precursors were removed. Further heating to 750 °C induced the transition from the amorphous phase to the crystalline phase, with the main diffraction peaks of the XRD pattern observed at 22.90° (110), 32.64° (112), and 46.65° (220) of an orthorhombic crystal structure of the perovskite-type SmFeO3 (JCPDS no. 74-2424). The crystal constants of the sample were calculated to be a = 0.5606 nm, b = 0.7721 nm, and c = 0.5408 nm. The HRTEM image displayed a lattice spacing of 0.39 nm corresponding to (110) of SmFeO3 (Figure a, right). The TEM images of the prepared SmFeO3 were porous, comprising small SmFeO3 nanoparticles of 20−40 nm in diameter, enabling us to recognize the starting asterisk morphology (Figure a, left), even though some parts of the crystals were broken because of their fragility. The phase transition from amorphous to crystalline accompanies the significant decrease of the BET surface area from 175.2 to 9.7 m2/g due to the calcination among the components (Table ). Upon further heating to 950 °C, the arm-like network of SmFeO3 was predominant with the BET surface area of 7.5 m2/g (Figure b, Table ), which is understandable considering that the adjacent SmFeO3 asterisk arms were connected by the thermal treatment. It was demonstrated that the morphology of the final perovskite-type nanoceramics was strongly influenced by that of the starting MOF precursor.
elements.clean_text: Figure  shows the XRD patterns of the Fe−CN−Sm nanoasterisks calcined in air at different temperatures as a powdery form. The pattern of the sample heated to below 550 °C did not exhibit distinct diffraction peaks, displaying a broadened peak in the low angle region at approximately 30°. The sample was considered to be an amorphous phase, which agrees well with the in situ thermal TEM observations (see above). The constituents of SmFeO3 (Sm, Fe, and O ions) did not crystallize, even though the bridging CN ligands of the Fe−CN−Sm nanoasterisk precursors were removed. Further heating to 750 °C induced the transition from the amorphous phase to the crystalline phase, with the main diffraction peaks of the XRD pattern observed at 22.90° (110), 32.64° (112), and 46.65° (220) of an orthorhombic crystal structure of the perovskite-type SmFeO3 (JCPDS no. 74-2424). The crystal constants of the sample were calculated to be a = 0.5606 nm, b = 0.7721 nm, and c = 0.5408 nm. The HRTEM image displayed a lattice spacing of 0.39 nm corresponding to (110) of SmFeO3 (Figure a, right). The TEM images of the prepared SmFeO3 were porous, comprising small SmFeO3 nanoparticles of 20−40 nm in diameter, enabling us to recognize the starting asterisk morphology (Figure a, left), even though some parts of the crystals were broken because of their fragility. The phase transition from amorphous to crystalline accompanies the significant decrease of the BET surface area from 175.2 to 9.7 m2/g due to the calcination among the components (Table ). Upon further heating to 950 °C, the arm-like network of SmFeO3 was predominant with the BET surface area of 7.5 m2/g (Figure b, Table ), which is understandable considering that the adjacent SmFeO3 asterisk arms were connected by the thermal treatment. It was demonstrated that the morphology of the final perovskite-type nanoceramics was strongly influenced by that of the starting MOF precursor.

elements.content: In summary, we presented the novel synthesis of nanometric lanthanide hexacyanoferrate Fe−CN−Ln in a water/alcohol solution containing acetic acid. The morphology of Fe−CN−Ln was highly dependent on the type of Ln, which was categorized as a hexagon, asterisk, or rod. The most specific morphology of an asterisk was prepared with a high selectivity of over 80% by the introduction of Sm. The formation mechanism of the prepared Fe−CN−Sm nanoasterisks was revealed by TEM and HRTEM, showing that they were composed of tiny assembled polycrystalline structures. Thermal TEM observation presented in situ decomposition dynamics through which the starting nanoasterisk was converted to an amorphous hollow nanostructure below 550 °C, with a significant increase in the BET surface area while retaining the starting morphology. Further heating induced a phase transition to provide quasi-asterisks (750 °C) or arm-connected perovskite-type SmFeO3 nanostructures (950 °C). We believe that this study affords a scientific and technological direction toward sophisticated nanomaterial architecture using a bottom-up approach. The demand for effective techniques for making novel nanomaterials will increase in the future.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions
In summary, we presented the novel synthesis of nanometric lanthanide hexacyanoferrate Fe−CN−Ln in a water/alcohol solution containing acetic acid. The morphology of Fe−CN−Ln was highly dependent on the type of Ln, which was categorized as a hexagon, asterisk, or rod. The most specific morphology of an asterisk was prepared with a high selectivity of over 80% by the introduction of Sm. The formation mechanism of the prepared Fe−CN−Sm nanoasterisks was revealed by TEM and HRTEM, showing that they were composed of tiny assembled polycrystalline structures. Thermal TEM observation presented in situ decomposition dynamics through which the starting nanoasterisk was converted to an amorphous hollow nanostructure below 550 °C, with a significant increase in the BET surface area while retaining the starting morphology. Further heating induced a phase transition to provide quasi-asterisks (750 °C) or arm-connected perovskite-type SmFeO3 nanostructures (950 °C). We believe that this study affords a scientific and technological direction toward sophisticated nanomaterial architecture using a bottom-up approach. The demand for effective techniques for making novel nanomaterials will increase in the future.

metadata.title:
Nanometric Metal−Organic Framework of Ln[Fe(CN)6]: Morphological Analysis and Thermal Conversion Dynamics by Direct TEM Observation
Nanometric Metal−Organic Framework of Ln[Fe(CN)6]
